instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
Very clean board with the exception of a little blue around <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>. Magsafe green then orange. 
Cleaned area with no change. Replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> and cleaned under <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. All resistors around test good. 

Mac came to me with a chinese charger so I switched attention to ISL. Replaced twice, no change. Just replaced SMC and again no change.  

Anything else the charger could have killed? 

8.57 on <SIGNAL>PPBUSG_3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
Apart of good <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, you didn't post too much information to start helping you.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS at least?
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS - both are 3.3v
smc bypass was tried while in the case and from the board. 

Weird symptom - I get amber magsafe without I/O cable attached. This normally doesnt happen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk, no LIO flex connected, only 5 pins DC cable.
No SSD, airport, LCD or anything else.
Just check if voltages appear on big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message: ^this is how I tested the board. With the exception of flex cable. Same results without it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If present, check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops to .361 for a few seconds then back up. 

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulses on its own from 0v to .8v-1.3v every 5 seconds. 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses on its own from 0v to .8v-1.3v every 5 seconds. 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulses on its own from 0v to .8v-1.3v every 5 seconds. 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> pulses on its own from .06v to .8v-1.3v every 5 seconds.

Triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> does nothing to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>

Swapped the SMC again from a working board. no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
So power cycling every 5s, you didn't mention this in first post.

Check for pulse at all big coils at same time.
Also chek at pins 3 & 7 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
Big coils like L7320 are cycling. I guess I missed this. No fan FYI. 
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 7 is the same but pin 3 cycles only to .18v not as high as the others.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
Fast pulse is not easy to ctach with DC voltmeter.
An o-scope can catch the peak level of any fast pulse.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

You can try known good BIOS, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible chinese charger damage
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6128</RESISTOR> pin 1 trace and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> trace to <RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> were severed. Couldn't determine visibly, only by testing. 

Working now. Thanks for your help.
